ai-sn17:1.1.2_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
ai-sn17:1.2.1_0: “Possessions, honor, and popularity are brutal, bitter, and harsh. They’re an obstacle to reaching the supreme sanctuary.
ai-sn17:1.2.2_0: So you should train like this:
ai-sn17:1.2.3_0: ‘We will give up arisen possessions, honor, and popularity, and we won’t let them occupy our minds.’
ai-sn17:2.1.2_0: “Possessions, honor, and popularity are brutal, bitter, and harsh. They’re an obstacle to reaching the supreme sanctuary.
ai-sn17:2.1.3_0: Suppose a fisherman was to cast a baited hook into a deep lake.
ai-sn17:2.1.4_0: Seeing the bait, a fish would swallow it.
ai-sn17:2.1.5_0: And so the fish that swallowed the hook would meet with tragedy and disaster, and the fisherman can do what he wants with it.
ai-sn17:2.2.1_0: ‘Fisherman’ is a term for Māra the Wicked.
ai-sn17:2.2.2_0: ‘A snake’ is a term for possessions, honor, and popularity.
ai-sn17:2.2.3_0: Whoever enjoys and likes arisen possessions, honor, and popularity is called a mendicant who has swallowed Māra’s hook. They’ve met with tragedy and disaster, and the Wicked One can do what he wants with them.
ai-sn17:2.2.4_0: So brutal are possessions, honor, and popularity—bitter and harsh, an obstacle to reaching the supreme sanctuary.
ai-sn17:2.2.5_0: So you should train like this:
ai-sn17:2.2.6_0: ‘We will give up arisen possessions, honor, and popularity, and we won’t let them occupy our minds.’
ai-sn17:3.1.3_0: Once upon a time in a certain lake there was a large family of turtles that had lived there for a long time.
ai-sn17:3.1.4_0: Then one of the turtles said to another,
ai-sn17:3.1.5_0: ‘My dear turtle, don’t you go to that place.’
ai-sn17:3.1.6_0: But that turtle did go to that place,
ai-sn17:3.1.7_0: and a hunter pierced her with a harpoon.
ai-sn17:3.1.8_0: Then that turtle went back to the other turtle.
ai-sn17:3.1.9_0: When the other turtle saw her coming off in the distance,
ai-sn17:3.1.11_0: ‘My dear turtle, I hope you didn’t go to that place!’
ai-sn17:3.1.12_0: ‘My dear turtle, I gave it to you!’
ai-sn17:3.1.13_0: ‘But my dear turtle, I hope you’re not hurt or injured!’
ai-sn17:3.1.14_0: ‘I’m not hurt or injured. But this cord keeps dragging behind me.’
ai-sn17:3.1.15_0: ‘Indeed, my dear turtle, you’ve broken the stomach!
ai-sn17:3.1.16_0: Your father and grandfather met with tragedy and disaster because of such a cord.
ai-sn17:3.1.17_0: Go now, you are no longer one of us.’
ai-sn17:3.2.1_0: ‘Hunter’ is a term for Māra the Wicked.
ai-sn17:3.2.2_0: ‘Harpoon’ is a term for possessions, honor, and popularity.
ai-sn17:3.2.3_0: ‘Cord’ is a term for greed and relishing.
ai-sn17:3.2.4_0: Whoever enjoys and likes arisen possessions, honor, and popularity while possessions, honor, and popularity
ai-sn17:3.2.5_0: they’re called a mendicant who has swallowed Māra’s hook. They’ve met with tragedy and disaster, and the Wicked One can do what he wants with them.
ai-sn17:3.2.6_0: So brutal are possessions, honor, and popularity. ...”
ai-sn17:4.1.3_0: Suppose a fleecy sheep was to enter a briar patch.
ai-sn17:4.1.4_0: She’d get caught, snagged, and trapped at every turn, coming to ruin.
ai-sn17:4.1.5_0: In the same way, take a certain mendicant whose mind is overcome and overwhelmed by possessions, honor, and popularity. They robe up in the morning and, taking their bowl and robe, enter the village or town for alms.
ai-sn17:4.1.6_0: They get caught, snagged, and trapped at every turn, coming to ruin.
ai-sn17:4.1.7_0: So brutal are possessions, honor, and popularity. ...”
ai-sn17:5.1.3_0: Suppose there was a dung-eating beetle full of dung, stuffed with dung, and before her was a huge pile of dung.
ai-sn17:5.1.4_0: She’d look down on other beetles, thinking:
ai-sn17:5.1.5_0: ‘For I am a dung-eating beetle full of dung, stuffed with dung, and before me is a huge pile of dung.’
ai-sn17:5.1.6_0: In the same way, take a certain mendicant whose mind is overcome and overwhelmed by possessions, honor, and popularity. They robe up in the morning and, taking their bowl and robe, enter the village or town for alms.
ai-sn17:5.1.7_0: There they eat as much as they like, get invited back tomorrow, and have plenty of alms-food.
ai-sn17:5.1.8_0: When they get back to the monastery, they boast in the middle of a group of mendicants:
ai-sn17:5.1.9_0: ‘I ate as much as I liked, got invited back tomorrow, and had plenty of alms-food. I get robes, alms-food, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick. But these other mendicants have little merit or significance, so they don’t get these things.’
ai-sn17:5.1.10_0: Because of that, his mind was overcome and overwhelmed by possessions, honor, and popularity.
ai-sn17:5.1.11_0: This will be for their lasting harm and suffering.
ai-sn17:5.1.12_0: So brutal are possessions, honor, and popularity. ...”
ai-sn17:6.1.3_0: Who should be struck by lightning? A trainee who comes into possessions, honor, and popularity before they achieve their heart’s desire.
ai-sn17:6.2.1_0: ‘Lightning strike’ is a term for possessions, honor, and popularity.
ai-sn17:6.2.2_0: So brutal are possessions, honor, and popularity. ...”
ai-sn17:6.2.4_0: The sixth offering to an individual.
ai-sn17:7.1.3_0: Who is striving along with a dart who is talking about possessions, honor, and popularity before they achieve their heart’s desire.
ai-sn17:7.2.1_0: ‘Arrow’ is a term for possessions, honor, and popularity.
ai-sn17:7.2.2_0: So brutal are possessions, honor, and popularity. ...”
ai-sn17:8.1.3_0: Mendicants, did you hear an old jackal howling at the crack of dawn?”
ai-sn17:8.1.5_0: “That old jackal has the disease called mange. He’s not happy in his den, or at the root of a tree, or out in the open.
ai-sn17:8.1.6_0: Wherever he goes, stands, sits, or lies down he sits down,
ai-sn17:8.1.7_0: In the same way, take a mendicant whose mind is overcome and overwhelmed by possessions, honor, and popularity. They don’t take pleasure in it.
ai-sn17:8.1.8_0: Wherever he goes, stands, sits, or lies down he sits down,
ai-sn17:8.1.9_0: So brutal are possessions, honor, and popularity. ...”
ai-sn17:9.1.3_0: High in the sky there are gale-force winds blowing.
ai-sn17:9.1.4_0: Any bird that flies there is flung about by those gale-force winds.
ai-sn17:9.1.5_0: As they do so, their body goes away.
ai-sn17:9.1.6_0: In the same way, take a certain monk whose mind is overcome and overwhelmed by possessions, honor, and popularity. He robes up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, enters the village or town for alms without guarding body, speech, and mind, without establishing mindfulness, and without restraining the sense faculties.
ai-sn17:9.1.7_0: There he sees a female scantily clad, with revealing clothes.
ai-sn17:9.1.9_0: so they resign the training and return to a lesser life.
ai-sn17:9.1.10_0: Some take his robe, others his bowl, others his sitting cloth, others his needle case, just like the bird flung about by the gale-force winds.
ai-sn17:9.1.11_0: So brutal are possessions, honor, and popularity. ...”
ai-sn17:10.1.3_0: Take another case where I see a certain person whose mind is overcome and overwhelmed by honor. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.
ai-sn17:10.1.4_0: Take another case where I see a certain person whose mind is overcome and overwhelmed by lack of honor. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.
ai-sn17:10.1.5_0: And take another case where I see a certain person whose mind is overcome and overwhelmed by both honor and lack of honor. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.
ai-sn17:10.1.6_0: So brutal are possessions, honor, and popularity. ...”
ai-sn17:10.2.1_0: That is what the Buddha said.
ai-sn17:10.2.2_0: Then the Holy One, the Teacher, went on to say:
ai-sn17:10.4.4_0: they’re said to be a good person.”
ai-sn17:11.1.3_0: When I’ve comprehended the mind of a certain person, I understand:
ai-sn17:11.1.4_0: ‘This venerable would not tell a deliberate lie even for the sake of a golden bowl filled with silver powder.’
ai-sn17:11.1.5_0: But some time later I see them tell a deliberate lie because their mind is overcome and overwhelmed by possessions, honor, and popularity.
ai-sn17:11.1.6_0: So brutal are possessions, honor, and popularity. ...”
ai-sn17:12.1.3_0: When I’ve comprehended the mind of a certain person, I understand:
ai-sn17:12.1.4_0: ‘This venerable would not tell a deliberate lie even for the sake of a silver bowl filled with gold powder.’
ai-sn17:12.1.5_0: But some time later I see them tell a deliberate lie because their mind is overcome and overwhelmed by possessions, honor, and popularity.
ai-sn17:12.1.6_0: So brutal are possessions, honor, and popularity. ...”
ai-sn17:13-20.0.3_0: used for his golden plunges, and so on,
ai-sn17:13-20.1.2_0: “Mendicants, when I’ve comprehended the mind of a certain person, I understand:
ai-sn17:13-20.1.3_0: ‘This venerable would not tell a deliberate lie even for the sake of a gold coin.’ ...
ai-sn17:13-20.1.4_0: ‘... for the sake of a hundred gold coins.’ ...
ai-sn17:13-20.1.5_0: ‘... for the sake of a gold doubloon.’ ...
ai-sn17:13-20.1.6_0: ‘... for the sake of a hundred gold doubloons.’ ...
ai-sn17:13-20.1.7_0: ‘... for the sake of the whole earth full of gold.’ ...
ai-sn17:13-20.1.8_0: ‘... for any kind of material reward.’ ...
ai-sn17:13-20.1.10_0: ‘... for the sake of the finest lady in the land.’
ai-sn17:13-20.1.11_0: But some time later I see them tell a deliberate lie because their mind is overcome and overwhelmed by possessions, honor, and popularity.
ai-sn17:13-20.1.12_0: So brutal are possessions, honor, and popularity. ...”
ai-sn17:13-20.2.4_0: The finest lady in the land is burning:
ai-sn17:21.1.3_0: Even if you’re alone with a female she might not occupy your mind, but possessions, honor and popularity would still occupy your mind.
ai-sn17:21.1.4_0: So brutal are possessions, honor, and popularity. ...”
ai-sn17:22.1.3_0: Even if you’re not occupied by that fine deluded mind, possessions, honor, and popularity would still occupy your mind.
ai-sn17:22.1.4_0: So brutal are possessions, honor, and popularity. ...”
ai-sn17:23.1.3_0: A faithful laywoman with a dear and beloved only son would rightly appeal to him,
ai-sn17:23.1.4_0: ‘My darling, please be like the householder Citta and Hatthaka of Aḷavī.’
ai-sn17:23.1.5_0: These are a standard and a measure for my male lay followers, that is, the householder Citta and Hatthaka of Aḷavī.
ai-sn17:23.1.6_0: ‘But my darling, if you go forth from the lay life to homelessness,
ai-sn17:23.1.7_0: please be like Sāriputta and Moggallāna.’
ai-sn17:23.1.8_0: These are a standard and a measure for my monk disciples, that is, Sāriputta and Moggallāna.
ai-sn17:23.1.9_0: ‘And my darling, may you not come into possessions, honor, and popularity while you’re still a trainee and haven’t achieved your heart’s desire.’
ai-sn17:23.1.10_0: If a trainee who hasn’t achieved their heart’s desire comes into possessions, honor, and popularity it’s an obstacle for them.
ai-sn17:23.1.11_0: So brutal are possessions, honor, and popularity. ...”
ai-sn17:24.1.3_0: A faithful laywoman with a dear and beloved only daughter would rightly appeal to her,
ai-sn17:24.1.4_0: ‘Venerables, please be like the laywomen Khujjuttarā and Veḷukaṇṭakī, Nanda’s mother.’
ai-sn17:24.1.5_0: These are a standard and a measure for my female lay disciples, that is, the laywomen Khujjuttarā and Veḷukaṇṭakī, Nanda’s mother.
ai-sn17:24.1.6_0: ‘But my darling, if you go forth from the lay life to homelessness, please be like the nuns Khemā and Uppalavaṇṇā.’
ai-sn17:24.1.7_0: Sir, you should be like that.
ai-sn17:24.1.8_0: These are a standard and a measure for my nun disciples, that is, the nuns Khemā and Uppalavaṇṇā.
ai-sn17:24.1.9_0: ‘Venerable, don’t come into possessions, honor, and popularity while you’re still a trainee and haven’t achieved your heart’s desire.’
ai-sn17:24.1.10_0: If a trainee who hasn’t achieved their heart’s desire comes into possessions, honor, and popularity it’s an obstacle for them.
ai-sn17:24.1.11_0: So brutal are possessions, honor, and popularity. ...”
ai-sn17:25.1.2_0: “Mendicants, there are ascetics and brahmins who don’t truly understand the gratification, drawback, and escape when it comes to possessions, honor, and popularity.
ai-sn17:25.1.3_0: I don’t regard them as true ascetics and brahmins. Those venerables don’t realize the goal of life as an ascetic or brahmin, and don’t live having realized it with their own insight.
ai-sn17:25.1.4_0: There are ascetics and brahmins who do truly understand the gratification, drawback, and escape when it comes to possessions, honor, and popularity.
ai-sn17:25.1.5_0: I regard them as true ascetics and brahmins. Those venerables realize the goal of life as an ascetic or brahmin, and live having realized it with their own insight.”
ai-sn17:26.1.2_0: “There are ascetics and brahmins who don’t truly understand the origin, ending, gratification, drawback, and escape when it comes to possessions, honor, and popularity ...
ai-sn17:26.1.4_0: There are ascetics and brahmins who do truly understand ... Those venerables realize the goal of life as an ascetic or brahmin, and live having realized it with their own insight.”
ai-sn17:26.1.5_0: The sixth offering to an individual.
ai-sn17:27.1.2_0: “There are ascetics and brahmins who don’t truly understand possessions, honor, and popularity ...
ai-sn17:27.1.4_0: There are ascetics and brahmins who do truly understand ... Those venerables realize the goal of life as an ascetic or brahmin, and live having realized it with their own insight.”
ai-sn17:28.1.3_0: possessions, honor, and popularity cut through the outer skin, the inner skin, the flesh, sinews, and bones, until they reach the marrow and stay pressing there.
ai-sn17:28.1.4_0: So brutal are possessions, honor, and popularity. ...”
ai-sn17:29.1.3_0: possessions, honor, and popularity cut through the outer skin, the inner skin, the flesh, sinews, and bones, until they reach the marrow and stay pressing there.
ai-sn17:29.2.1_0: It’s like how a strong person can extend or contract their arm.
ai-sn17:29.2.2_0: It would cut through the outer skin, the inner skin, the flesh, sinews, and bones, until it reached the marrow and stayed pressing there.
ai-sn17:29.2.3_0: In the same way, possessions, honor, and popularity cut through the outer skin, the inner skin, the flesh, sinews, and bones, until they reach the marrow and stay pressing there.
ai-sn17:29.2.4_0: So brutal are possessions, honor, and popularity. ...”
ai-sn17:30.1.2_0: “Mendicants, possessions, honor, and popularity are an obstacle even for a mendicant who is perfected, with defilements ended.”
ai-sn17:30.1.3_0: After this was said, venerable Ānanda addressed the Fortunate One, (saying):
ai-sn17:30.1.4_0: “Sir, what do possessions, honor, and popularity obstruct for a mendicant with defilements ended?”
ai-sn17:30.1.5_0: “Ānanda, I don’t say that possessions, honor, and popularity obstruct the unshakable freedom of heart.
ai-sn17:30.1.6_0: But I do say that possessions, honor, and popularity obstruct the achievement of blissful meditations in this very life for a meditator who is diligent, keen, and resolute.
ai-sn17:30.1.7_0: So brutal are possessions, honor, and popularity—bitter and harsh, an obstacle to reaching the supreme sanctuary.
ai-sn17:30.1.8_0: So you should train like this:
ai-sn17:30.1.9_0: ‘We will give up arisen possessions, honor, and popularity, and we won’t let them occupy our minds.’
ai-sn17:30.1.12_0: The third sub-chapter on lying down is finished.
ai-sn17:30.2.4_0: A mendicant who meditates on these six senses,
ai-sn17:31.1.3_0: Devadatta split the Saṅgha because his mind was overcome and overwhelmed by possessions, honor, and popularity.
ai-sn17:31.1.4_0: So brutal are possessions, honor, and popularity. ...”
ai-sn17:32.1.3_0: Devadatta cut off his skillful quality because his mind was overcome and overwhelmed by possessions, honor, and popularity.
ai-sn17:32.1.4_0: So brutal are possessions, honor, and popularity. ...”
ai-sn17:33.1.3_0: Devadatta cut off his skillful quality because his mind was overcome and overwhelmed by possessions, honor, and popularity.
ai-sn17:33.1.4_0: So brutal are possessions, honor, and popularity. ...”
ai-sn17:34.1.3_0: Devadatta cut off his bright quality because his mind was overcome and overwhelmed by possessions, honor, and popularity.
ai-sn17:34.1.4_0: So brutal are possessions, honor, and popularity. ...”
ai-sn17:35.1.1_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, on the Vulture’s Peak Mountain, not long after Devadatta had left.
ai-sn17:35.1.2_0: There the Buddha spoke to the mendicants about Devadatta:
ai-sn17:35.1.3_0: “Possessions, honor, and popularity came to Devadatta for his own ruin and downfall.
ai-sn17:35.2.2_0: so too do Devadatta’s gain, honor, and fame cause his own destruction and ruin.
ai-sn17:35.3.2_0: so too do Devadatta’s gain, honor, and fame cause his own destruction and ruin.
ai-sn17:35.4.1_0: or a reed, all of which bear fruit to their own ruin and downfall ...
ai-sn17:35.4.2_0: so too do Devadatta’s gain, honor, and fame cause his own destruction and ruin.
ai-sn17:35.5.1_0: Just as a mule becomes pregnant for its own destruction and ruin,
ai-sn17:35.5.2_0: so too do Devadatta’s gain, honor, and fame cause his own destruction and ruin.
ai-sn17:35.5.3_0: So brutal are possessions, honor, and popularity. ...”
ai-sn17:35.6.1_0: That is what the Buddha said.
ai-sn17:35.6.2_0: Then the Holy One, the Teacher, went on to say:
ai-sn17:35.7.2_0: And the bamboo and the reed.
ai-sn17:36.1.1_0: Near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.
ai-sn17:36.1.2_0: Now at that time Prince Ajātasattu was going with five hundred carts in the morning and the evening to attend on Devadatta, presenting him with an offering of five hundred servings of food.
ai-sn17:36.1.3_0: Then many monks went to the Fortunate One,
ai-sn17:36.1.3_1: After bowing down to the Buddha, they sat down,
ai-sn17:36.1.4_0: “Sir, King Ajātasattu goes with five hundred carts in the morning and the evening to attend on him in the morning and evening to attend on him morning and evening.”
ai-sn17:36.1.5_0: “Don’t envy Devadatta, monks, his gain, honor, and fame.
ai-sn17:36.1.6_0: As long as Prince Ajātasattu goes with five hundred carts in the morning and the evening to attend on Devadatta, presenting him with an offering of five hundred servings of food, Devadatta can expect decline, not growth, in skillful qualities.
ai-sn17:36.2.1_0: If bile were to burst from a wild dog’s nose, it would become even wilder.
ai-sn17:36.2.2_0: In the same way, as long as Prince Ajātasattu goes with five hundred carts in the morning and the evening to attend on Devadatta, presenting him with an offering of five hundred servings of food, Devadatta can expect decline, not growth, in skillful qualities.
ai-sn17:36.2.3_0: So brutal are possessions, honor, and popularity. ...”
ai-sn17:36.2.5_0: The sixth offering to an individual.
ai-sn17:37.1.2_0: “Possessions, honor, and popularity are brutal, bitter, and harsh. They’re an obstacle to reaching the supreme sanctuary.
ai-sn17:37.1.3_0: When I’ve comprehended the mind of a certain person, I understand:
ai-sn17:37.1.4_0: ‘This venerable would not tell a deliberate lie even for the sake of their mother.’
ai-sn17:37.1.5_0: But some time later I see them tell a deliberate lie because their mind is overcome and overwhelmed by possessions, honor, and popularity.
ai-sn17:37.1.6_0: So brutal are possessions, honor, and popularity—bitter and harsh, an obstacle to reaching the supreme sanctuary.
ai-sn17:37.1.7_0: So you should train like this:
ai-sn17:37.1.8_0: ‘We will give up arisen possessions, honor, and popularity.
ai-sn17:37.1.9_0: and you won’t occupy your mind.’
ai-sn17:38-43.1.2_0: “Possessions, honor, and popularity are brutal, bitter, and harsh. They’re an obstacle to reaching the supreme sanctuary.
ai-sn17:38-43.1.3_0: When I’ve comprehended the mind of a certain person, I understand:
ai-sn17:38-43.1.4_0: ‘This venerable would not tell a deliberate lie even for the sake of their father. ...
ai-sn17:38-43.1.6_0: at the sake of his brother ...
ai-sn17:38-43.1.8_0: ‘... for the sake of a child ...’ ...
ai-sn17:38-43.1.11_0: But some time later I see them tell a deliberate lie because their mind is overcome and overwhelmed by possessions, honor, and popularity.
ai-sn17:38-43.1.12_0: So brutal are possessions, honor, and popularity—bitter and harsh, an obstacle to reaching the supreme sanctuary.
ai-sn17:38-43.1.13_0: So you should train like this:
ai-sn17:38-43.1.14_0: ‘We will give up arisen possessions, honor, and popularity, and we won’t let them occupy our minds.’
ai-sn17:38-43.1.17_0: The fourth sub-chapter on lying down is finished.
ai-sn17:38-43.2.1_0: break up the roots, misery, and bad things have been done.
ai-sn17:38-43.2.5_0: The Linked Discourses on possessions, honor, and popularity are complete.
